{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3254855,"name":"Theresa","username":"CoachT","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/coacht/{size}/198803_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-17T14:59:47.794Z","cooked":"

Our team has purchased SDS MK4i modules and are currently assembling them.

I’m thinking ahead and was curious if teams have run into issues with any of the threaded holes in the aluminum parts stripping out overtime?

If so, which locations are the most problematic?
I’m wondering if we should preemptively install Heli-Coils

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-11-17T15:00:56.544Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":39,"reads":523,"readers_count":522,"score":319.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":444478,"topic_slug":"sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped","display_username":"Theresa","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16416,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor / Alum | FRC 1099 The DiscoTechs"},"post_url":"/t/sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped/444478/1","custom_user_title":"Mentor / Alum | FRC 1099 The DiscoTechs","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3254863,"name":"Wes","username":"Rally","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rally/{size}/201273_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-17T15:11:01.063Z","cooked":"

I’ve never heard of any failures with them, aluminum can hold a thread just fine if you have the right thickness

We had an issue once when we first started when the holes used for mounting stripped after impact in 2020 offseason. It was pretty much our fault though we didn’t have any bolts on top…

The Mk4i wasn’t around in 2020 or even 2021

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-11-17T16:29:31.532Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":408,"readers_count":407,"score":131.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":444478,"topic_slug":"sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":34970,"username":"mdurrani834","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mdurrani834/{size}/131246_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53198,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"My views are mine and mine alone"},"post_url":"/t/sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped/444478/6","custom_user_title":"My views are mine and mine alone","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3254945,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-11-17T17:03:57.709Z","cooked":"

There are three reasons why the threads get stripped.

The first is the plates being defective in some way. I am not aware of any teams encountering this problem.

The second is inadequate training. Team members can over-tighten the screws if they have not been trained adequately. Many (most) students do not have sufficient prior experience to know what it feels like to adequately tighten a screw and when they have over-tightened and stripped the threads.

The third is choosing the wrong people to do the work. Some people have good fine motor control abilities and are careful and meticulous. They would be well suited to doing such assembly work. Some people do not have good fine motor control abilities and are less careful and meticulous. These tend to be characteristics that one is born with so unless one has a way to train such abilities, these people should be directed to types of work where such abilities are not required. In the working world, there are chalk carving tests that one must pass to be admitted to dental schools. No doubt, there are similar tests for surgeons and watch makers.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-11-17T17:03:57.709Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":382,"readers_count":381,"score":126.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":444478,"topic_slug":"sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped/444478/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3254950,"name":"Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons","username":"RicDV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ricdv/{size}/188502_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-17T17:11:11.018Z","cooked":"

Tell the kids when they start a bolt (regardless of type) to go in the opposite direction until they hear/feel it drop into the thread. Then go into the proper direction. Over tightening is just as bad.

This is a habit I have been in for decades. And I pass on that learning to the next generation.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-11-17T17:11:11.018Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":354,"readers_count":353,"score":225.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":444478,"topic_slug":"sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped","display_username":"Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":12}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48664,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor 5503"},"post_url":"/t/sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped/444478/8","custom_user_title":"Mentor 5503","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3254976,"name":"","username":"mdurrani834","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mdurrani834/{size}/131246_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-17T17:42:37.186Z","cooked":"

Sorry this was MK3 Or MK4 but I think the experience still applies.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-11-17T17:42:37.186Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":323,"readers_count":322,"score":69.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":444478,"topic_slug":"sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53198,"username":"Thor5090","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thor5090/{size}/226064_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":34970,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped/444478/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3254977,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-17T17:42:45.710Z","cooked":"
RicDV:

start a bolt (regardless of type) to go in the opposite direction until they hear/feel it drop into the thread. Then go into the proper direction.

Bingo. Many of us learned this working on our high school beaters putting in those sparkplugs and other things into blind holes where all you had was the feeling from your fingers since you couldn’t really see what you were doing.

But it’s great even if that screw if in plain sight right in front of you.

Whilst there is a left and right hand bolts…and we go in the regular way…it is a great practice for all. Especially when we know the proper direction of turn!

CoachT:

I’m wondering if we should preemptively install Heli-Coils

With reasonable care and proper torque, those threads should last a long time as you don’t need to disassemble that often.

Given the expertise and growing skills of the folks typically doing the assembly, I’d go with training first and save the helicoils for when and if something goes south. That way you’ve got a backup fix.

It’s fortunate that the plates are thick enough to be able to use a threaded insert to get things back into action if something does go awry.

Make sure u go in straight. If the bolts come in at an angle they’ll cross thread the tap and doing it enough times will mess up the wheel. Not rushing the process is important bc it increases the chances of screw ups. Slow is smooth and smooth is fast.

The MK4i uses 7075 aluminum for the plates. 7075 has about double the yield strength of 6061. The threads in the plates are quite a bit stronger than what most people are used to from that thickness of aluminum plate.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2023-11-17T23:07:25.893Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":35.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":444478,"topic_slug":"sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped","display_username":"snoman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21744,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/sds-mk4i-threaded-holes-stripped/444478/17","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3255118,"name":"marshall","username":"marshall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/marshall/{size}/167657_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-17T23:19:20.428Z","cooked":"
philso:

The third is choosing the wrong people to do the work. Some people have good fine motor control abilities and are careful and meticulous. They would be well suited to doing such assembly work. Some people do not have good fine motor control abilities and are less careful and meticulous. These tend to be characteristics that one is born with so unless one has a way to train such abilities, these people should be directed to types of work where such abilities are not required. In the working world, there are chalk carving tests that one must pass to be admitted to dental schools. No doubt, there are similar tests for surgeons and watch makers.

This is all kinds of not-quite-right and possibly even flat-out-wrong.

These “manual dexterity” tests are largely not that useful for what they end up getting used for: Human Verification

Manual dexterity aptitude testing in the form of soap carving does not appear to correlate with surgical skill at the time of graduation from otolaryngology residency programs.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1041608008000289

Originally, this was a Chalk Carving Test, which involved interpreting a diagram of a geometric design and carving the design accurately in a block of chalk. However, in 1972, following extensive validation studies (Graham, 1972), this test was replaced by a paper-and-pencil test known as the Perceptual Ability Test (see sample items from this test in Fig. 1) so that the current practice in the U.S. is to measure spatial abilities on the basis of paper-and-pencil tests alone

https://scholarsrepository.llu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2556&context=etd

However, multiple studies have found that the PAT subtest scores had little to no role in predicting students’ performance by the end of dental school, suggesting that PAT scores may have limited value in predicting clinical achievement.

I am aware that this “testing” is still done in some places but it’s largely been removed.

Setting that one aside though… we get to this:

These tend to be characteristics that one is born with

This is the point I have the biggest issue with… it’s just wrong. I wasn’t born with any ability to turn a screwdriver. I’m watching my own kid as he is growing and developing and he wasn’t born with it either but he is learning. That’s kinda what kids do.

Students can and will learn when given the opportunity. If you want to get students used to the feeling of overtightened bolts then invest in some bolts for them to over tighten and strip. A tap into some scrap 1/8" or 1/4" aluminum isn’t that hard to do and can be used as a learning exercise.

Students are not born with this ability, nor should we expect them to be.
